Description:
I Was An MIT Educated Neurosurgeon Now I'm Unemployed And Alone In The Mountains How Did I Get Here?

Relevant quotes
"The focus of medicine wasn't in the right place. It wasn't in healing‚Äîit was in making money from surgeries and pills" (30:38)
"If you figure out a way to help patients heal and that way doesn't include a pill or a surgery... well then the hospital and the doctor are in big trouble" (26:24)
"The incentives are not right in the whole system... it's not about prevention, it's about therapies" (31:06)
"If you figure out a way to help people heal and you can't charge them for it, well then you've just worked yourself out of a job" (26:48)

Description:
Everyone thought the implementation of electronic health records would be a massive upgrade in efficiency and productivity. 

Then we regulated it so that only cumbersome, outdated software was allowed in Medicare. We let incumbents write the rules regulating the market. They throttled competition and ensured we were left with crap that not only failed to deliver on the promise of technology but actually made the practice of medicine worse. It drove thousands of doctors into early retirement and transformed the art of medicine into the slog of data entry. 

So pardon me if I‚Äôm a little jaded about the promise of AI.

Description:
Because consolidation drives up prices. Independence practices such as ours continue to struggle while large ‚ÄúNon-Profit‚Äù health systems benefit from structural advantages such as 340b drug pricing, hospital outpatient departments ‚Ä¶ all while not paying taxes nor providing charity care. 

We accept Medicare and Medicaid and do not receive DSH payments, game payments nor 340b benefits ‚Ä¶ all while large hospital systems benefit from all of these government programs.

Description:
Doctors, no one is coming to save us, or our patients. Don‚Äôt expect the politicians, or our medical organizations to come to our rescue. It‚Äôs up to us! We surrendered our profession years ago to the suits, time to fight and take it back. Time to build our own system. Calling and emailing our reps hasnt worked, they are all compromised, persuaded only by money and lobbyists. 
We must:
1. Build more physician owned hospitals 
2. Align private practices together to negotiate insurances (health, malpractice, liability), purchasing(GPOS)
3. Form CINs(Clinically Integrated Networks)
4. Contract directly with employers
5. Expand DPC 
6. Pool knowledge and resources to support private practices
7. Form our own PAC and fund it to at least 50M then lobby on our behalf
8. Educate med students and residents

Description:
It was an honor to be recognized at the 2025 Anti-Monopoy Summit in Washington, DC ‚Äî alongside policymakers, small business owners, workers, and advocates ‚Äî for speaking out about what‚Äôs at stake in healthcare today.

Independent physician practices are under attack by healthcare monopolies, and patients are paying the price. We cannot accept ‚Äúinsurance care‚Äù as the new normal. We must fight for a system where doctors have a voice, where care comes before profit, and where patients come first.

Description:
I‚Äôve spent 10 years in the ER, fighting for patients at their most vulnerable.
Now, I‚Äôm fighting for doctors.

For thousands of years, the doctor-patient relationship was sacred.
In the U.S., it‚Äôs been hijacked‚Äî30+ years of corporate interests reshaping care for profit.

The consequences?
Burned-out doctors.
Frustrated patients.
Broken trust.

It's time we take it back.

Description: Medicine in this country is on life support ‚Äî and it‚Äôs not because of patients or science. It‚Äôs because insurance companies and hospital executives have hijacked care. Paper-pushers with zero clinical training decide what can and cannot be prescribed, delaying or denying lifesaving treatments while hiding behind ‚Äúpolicy‚Äù and ‚Äúcost containment.‚Äù Meanwhile, politicians and corporate boards meddle in care, turning doctors into fearful employees who obey billing codes instead of fighting for the sick human being in front of them.

Description: I am physically exhausted‚Ä¶ not from caring for patients ‚Äî that still fuels me every single day ‚Äî but from fighting a system that seems built to crush doctors who actually want to heal. Endless bureaucracy. Red tape so thick it strangles common sense. People with no clinical experience are deciding what care is ‚Äúallowed.‚Äù I finally understand why so many of my friends have left medicine. They didn‚Äôt stop caring; they couldn‚Äôt keep fighting a machine that puts paperwork over patients. We were trained to save lives, not to beg for approvals and defend every decision to a panel of strangers. Medicine is bleeding talent because the system rewards compliance rather than courage. Patients deserve better.

Description:
Physicians are not just good at practicing medicine, we are also very good about complaining. Complaining about hospital systems, health insurance companies, and the health system as a whole.

Are these complaints well founded? Of course they are! But simply complaining about it won't change much. It will just make the doctors' lounge more insufferable.

Should we lobby congress to get things change? Only if you want to achieve incremental change at a glacial pace in one of the most expensive ways possible.

Or, since physicians make the gears of the healthcare system run, we can simply stop participating in the games. Stop taking health insurance, stop working with large health systems. That is how real change actually happens.

If we don't have the creativity and risk taking ability to make it happen, it never will.

Description:
Burnout‚Äù is a term I don‚Äôt personally identify with.
That‚Äôs not to say it doesn‚Äôt exist‚Äîit absolutely does, and not just in medicine.

Burnout is defined as a state of emotional, physical, and mental exhaustion caused by excessive, prolonged, and unmanaged workplace stress. It‚Äôs characterized by three key elements:
‚Ä¢ overwhelming exhaustion
‚Ä¢ growing cynicism or mental distance from one‚Äôs work
‚Ä¢ a reduced sense of professional effectiveness

Description:
I sent this to the NY Times but they decided not to run the story
Subject: Systemic Non-Payment by Blue Cross Blue Shield Crippling NYC Medical Practices & Patient Care
Dear Editor,
I am writing to bring attention to a healthcare crisis. Blue Cross Blue Shield (BCBS) has not reimbursed medical practices for services rendered for over four years. This creates an untenable situation for providers and jeopardizes patient access to care.

Description:
I have long supported independent physician practices. They are a critical component of a healthy marketplace. However we are being squeezed continuously by larger entities and you don‚Äôt need to be in healthcare to know that we are not in healthy marketplace anymore. 

Physician ownership has plummeted and yet there is more burnout than ever. I truly believe that this is directly correlated.
